comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>For question 2e, I was wondering why the answer is sqrt(d_in * d_out) and not sqrt(d_out)? According to 2c, the solutions is that the max spectral norm of ∆W should be sqrt(d_out), and in 2e, I believe we just have to use this along with the fact that UV^T has spectral norm 1 to find the answer, as the spectral norm of ∆W is then just alpha.</paragraph><paragraph>In the answer key, it mentions that c is giving the factor of sqrt(d_in), but I think that's double counting the effect of c, as we already used that to isolate the max spectral norm of ∆W in part (c).</paragraph><paragraph>I've also seen a lot of special participation posts mentioning that LLMs failed on 2e because they got the answer sqrt(d_out), and having to convince the LLM that it was the answer in the answer key.</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
For question 2e, I was wondering why the answer is sqrt(d_in * d_out) and not sqrt(d_out)? According to 2c, the solutions is that the max spectral norm of ∆W should be sqrt(d_out), and in 2e, I believe we just have to use this along with the fact that UV^T has spectral norm 1 to find the answer, as the spectral norm of ∆W is then just alpha.

In the answer key, it mentions that c is giving the factor of sqrt(d_in), but I think that's double counting the effect of c, as we already used that to isolate the max spectral norm of ∆W in part (c).

I've also seen a lot of special participation posts mentioning that LLMs failed on 2e because they got the answer sqrt(d_out), and having to convince the LLM that it was the answer in the answer key.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I think <italic>\alpha = \sqrt{d_{out}}</italic> is correct and the provided solution key appears to contain an error. In part 2(c), the constraint <italic>||Delta(W)||_spec < sqrt{d_{out}}</italic> was explicitly derived by already accounting for the scaling factor <italic>c = 1/sqrt{d_{in}}</italic>. By setting <italic>\alpha = \sqrt{d_{in}d_{out}}</italic> in part 2(e), the solution key effectively applies the scaling factor <italic>c</italic> a second time, which is a double counting error that contradicts the spectral norm constraint established in the previous step.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: I think \alpha = \sqrt{d_{out}} is correct and the provided solution key appears to contain an error. In part 2(c), the constraint ||Delta(W)||_spec < sqrt{d_{out}} was explicitly derived by already accounting for the scaling factor c = 1/sqrt{d_{in}}. By setting \alpha = \sqrt{d_{in}d_{out}} in part 2(e), the solution key effectively applies the scaling factor c a second time, which is a double counting error that contradicts the spectral norm constraint established in the previous step.
